title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text: Welcome to Data Science Society’s R Bootcamp

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text:
Course Outline:
Installation
What kind of data are we using?
Reading in Data

BaseR and Tidyverse

use this page to teach tidyverse https://tidyverse.tidyverse.org/index.html

there’s a from readr option using the “import dataset” option from the environment pane

Wrangling Data

dplyr, for data manipulation
tidyr, for data tidying
cleaning, the difference between them all, and when they should all take place in the process

Visualization of Data

the glory of ggplot



Show the code
library(tidyverse)
iris %>%
    ggplot()+
    geom_point(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color = Species))+
    labs(
        title = "Title here",
        x = "Sepal Length", 
        y = "Sepal Width"
        )

such and such

setting up R in VSCode: https://github.com/REditorSupport/vscode-R or https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=REditorSupport.r or https://github.com/REditorSupport/vscode-R/wiki/Installation:-Windows

how can I use the wiki tab on the github page? What is the proper usage of it?




Show the code
import pandas as pd

dat = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Olympics.csv")

title: Reading Data
text:
Reading in data that is located on your computer


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

data1 <- read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/US_Population_200_Years.csv")

head(data1)


# A tibble: 6 × 7
   Rank City             Population  Year PopDate    Longitude Latitude
  <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>
1     1 New York, NY          33131  1790 06/01/1790     -73.9     40.7
2     2 Philadelphia, PA      44096  1790 06/01/1790     -75.1     40.0
3     3 Boston, MA            18320  1790 06/01/1790     -71.1     42.3
4     4 Charleston, SC        16359  1790 06/01/1790     -80.0     32.8
5     5 Baltimore, MD         13503  1790 06/01/1790     -76.6     39.3
6     7 Salem, MA              7921  1790 06/01/1790     -70.9     42.5


text here


Getting data from a URL


Show the code
import pandas as pd

data1 = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")

data1.head()


This will teach about how to get a dataset into RStudio so that we can use it.
There are different types of data, we won’t get into the nitty-gritty parts of it, but there is structured, semi-structured, and ustructured data. We will be playing around with structured data (think excel files). Examples of the other types of data are pictures, video, and audio files.

text:

Base R

title: Installation Tutorial
text: R is the magic software that lets us do cool things with data. RStudio is the interface for how to use R.

title: Installation
section: Second Comparison: BaseR vs the Tidyverse
text:
Second Comparison: BaseR vs the Tidyverse


Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required. If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don’t make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse.

Run this code in the console
install.packages("tidyverse")


Here is more on this if you’d like to look into it: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/base.html

title: Installation
section: Second Comparison: Base R vs the Tidyverse
text:
Second Comparison: Base R vs the Tidyverse


Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required. If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don’t make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse.

Run this code in the console to download the tidyverse
install.packages("tidyverse")
In order to be able to use this package, put this code at the top of your R Script or RMD file
library(tidyverse)


Below are examples of Base R to Tidyverse comparisons

Selecting Columns




Base R
df$column_name
df[[]]



Tidyverse
df %>% select()




Making New Columns



 Base R 

df$profit <- df$revenue - df$cost


Tidyverse

df %>% mutate(profit = revenue - cost)


or


mutate(df, profit = revenue - cost)




Filtering Data



Base R
df[df$temperature > 45]

Tidyverse
df %>% filter(temperature > 45)
or
filter(df, temperature > 45)

title: Installation
text:
Grouping & Summarising Data


Base R
I’m not sure how to do this yet…

Tidyverse
df %>% group_by(city) %>% summarise(Avg_House_Price = mean(house_price))

title: Installation
text:
Sorting Data


Base R
mtcars[order(mpg, -cyl),]

Tidyverse
mtcars %>% arrange(mpg, desc(cyl))
or
arrange(mtcars, mpg, desc(cyl))


 Check out this page for more comparisons.
Filtering Data in Base R:

https://www.mitchcraver.com/2021/06/15/subsetting-and-filtering-a-data-frame-in-r/
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/crunch/vignettes/filters.html
